reviewText: Whether or not you're a Kurt Vonnegut fan doesn't take into account how much it costs to either rent or buy this twenty seven minute short-film. It is not like you are getting a full-on cast like a movie or tv series. A couple of the lines are switched, and a lot of the shots are just long, silent sections.Reading the short story was more fulfilling than watching this short movie.
summary: Closer to the original short story than the one with Sean Astin, but not worth the price.

reviewText: Eye-opening, thought-provoking, and even troubling 2081 depicts Vonnegut's dystopic short story in its truest form. The soundtrack is truly haunting.

reviewText: Unless you are burning up with curiosity to see this and have nothing better to spend your money on or have a gift certificate with only a few dollars left on it ...go for it. The written short story is better with using your own imagination. This reminds me of a 20 minute long trailer for a pretentious art film. I find it more of an insult to Vonnegut's work. That's just me. If you want to watch some great actors and the Vonnegut himself pay tribute with a cameo... Watch the film MotherNight with Nick Nolte.

reviewText: This is a RARE case  of  a  movie, though being faithful to the Kurt Vonnegut short story,  not  living up to the ORIGINAL movie, starring  Sean Astin.  2081  is just not as entertaining and makes as strong a point as  the original  "Harrison Bergeron" . Why is HOLLYWOOD  'vaporizing'  the original "Harrison Bergeron"?  I  want to see it available for purchase as a DVD.  I  fear  the same thing that happened to  "The Myth of the Spanish Inquisition"  an  A&E/BBC  documentary, with  Andrew Sachs  ('Manuel'  of Fawlty Towers' fame)  narrating.  It too apparently  struck a raw nerve, and  exposed many truths which are not stylish and politically correct in today's  Sanitized For Your Protection  Society.  I  hope there are enough of us out here who can comment and be heard about making both of these excellent videos available to the public,  ONCE MORE,  in  DVD form.  You can't even find either of them on VHS  anymore,  new or used!
summary: Nothing Beats The Original Harrison Bergeron
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a very well done short. The major motion pictures could learn a thing or two from this filmaker who seemed to know just what to leave in and what to edit out from the original Vonnegut story and still achieve the same point he was trying to make. The point is an reductio ad absurdum on substantial equality that rings true in our day and age.

reviewText: I've only just seen this short film moments ago. The reaction is still sinking in. It was poignant and moving, a powerful message I really felt. Our gifts are beautiful and should be marveled at and embraced not hidden for the sake of equality. Fight those that would control us and contain us, robbing us of our intelligence and our gifts.

reviewText: Vonnegut fans will appreciate this well done rendition despite the short duration of the film. Clocking in at only 25 minutes, 2081 is not exactly enough to fill "movie night" but what it lacks in length it more than makes up for in substance. For those that wonder how well the somewhat elusive and reflective nature of the story will play out on film...the answer is "surprisingly well".The premise is simple enough, a dystopian future where equality for all has finally been realized through the use of facial masks for the beautiful, body weights for the strong and neural impediments for the smart. Those extraordinary individuals who cannot conform to mediocrity are subject to state sponsored rehabilitation that borders on torture.Although set in the future, the thought provoking premise will leave some viewers wondering if the future is already upon us.

reviewText: I don't know that there's much to this short film besides the concept itself. It's certainly a powerful concept and it's very well executed here. Everything is very well done and engaging, but as a short film, I felt myself wanting more. I haven't read the original short story, which I'd like to read, but it seems to me that that's the medium it's most powerful in.

reviewText: We all want equality, right?  But equality of opportunity or equality of outcome?  I'm for the former, but too many people in our county, which was founded in part on the concepts of individual liberty and self-determination, prefer the latter.  The movie shows an absurd extreme, but nevertheless, it gets the point across.

reviewText: This film was worth every nickel.  Totally on the bull's-eye social commentary.The guy in his living room who's been artificially equalized is priceless.If you're prone to be upset at how unfair certain things are in life or think that the government should fix everything that isn't fair, then don't watch this.  You won't like the message (if you pick up on it).

reviewText: From the first scene to the last including the last lines and nearly everything in between - what a work of art. The brilliance to keep it short as well. I didn't care for the short speech. It was out of place with the rest of the movie in that it was so unnecessary. Just the line about the "the greatest man you......." as an introduction and then commencing with "the show" would have made the film completely perfect to me.What a beautiful horror this film is.
